newsitem.title: ECUADOR: Noboa says Ecuador mending its public finances.
newsitem.headline: Noboa says Ecuador mending its public finances.

text.p: Ecuador's new government is mending its public finances thanks to a stable exchange rate, a rise in international reserves and lower interest rates, said Alvaro Noboa, president of the policy-setting Monetary Board.

"In 23 days we achieved a stable dollar, (borrowing) interest rates lower than 55 percent and liquidity in the markets," Noboa, who took office with new President Abdala Bucaram August 10, told reporters Tuesday night.
Borrowing rates were at 62 percent before the change of government.
Noboa said that under a drive to reactivate the economy and create jobs the new administration will soon launch a low-income housing project and an agricultural development plan.
Bucaram's government is currently drafting a new economic program, to be announced in the next few month, aimed at plugging a budget deficit equal to 4.0 percent of GDP.

"Ecuador was so cash-strapped (when we took office) that if someone asked a financial institution for credit he was denied it, not because he didn't have good credentials but because the banks had no money," said Noboa.
He said the exchange rate was stable thanks to an inflow of dollars, which he did not quantify.
Noboa said international reserves had recovered to a record of $1.5 billion after shrinking to $1.3 billion in the final months of the government of former President Sixto Duran Ballen.
He also said he would promote price ceilings and floors for certain food products as part of a plan designed to boost the farming sector.
